lessons.title: 1.1 What is JavaScript?
lessons.content:
# What is JavaScript?

JavaScript is a lightweight, dynamic programming language that brings interactivity to web browsers.

## Definition

JavaScript is:

â€¢ **ðŸ”¥ Programming Language**: Uses syntax like C, Java, Python

â€¢ **âš¡ Interpreted Language**: Runs directly in browser without compilation

â€¢ **ðŸ’  Dynamic Typing**: Data types can change at runtime

â€¢ **ðŸ“ Event-Driven**: Responds to user actions (clicks, typing, etc.)

â€¢ **âœ… Client-Side**: Runs on user's browser, not server

## History

â€¢ **1995**: Created by Brendan Eich in 10 days

â€¢ **Originally Named**: Mocha â†’ LiveScript â†’ JavaScript

â€¢ **Purpose**: Add interactivity to static HTML pages

â€¢ **ES6 (2015)**: Major update that modernized the language

## Why JavaScript?

### âœ¨ Universal
- Runs in every browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
- No installation needed
- Works on desktop, mobile, servers (Node.js)

### ðŸš€ Powerful
- Build complete applications
- Create interactive user interfaces
- Handle real-time data
- Communicate with servers

### ðŸ“¦ Easy to Learn
- Simple syntax
- Immediate feedback
- Large community
- Tons of libraries & frameworks

## Real-World Applications

**Web Applications:**
- Facebook, Google Maps, Netflix
- Gmail, Slack, Figma
- VS Code (built with JavaScript)

**Mobile Apps:**
- React Native, Flutter (can use JS)
- Electron (desktop apps)

**Backend:**
- Node.js servers
- Database operations
- API creation

## JavaScript Today

JavaScript has evolved from simple form validation to:
- Full-stack web development
- Real-time chat applications
- Machine learning in browser
- Game development
- IoT (Internet of Things)
lessons.expectedOutput:
Console:
Hello, JavaScript!
Welcome to the JavaScript journey!

Browser:
Alert box showing: JavaScript is awesome!

quizQuestions.text: Who created JavaScript?
quizQuestions.explanation: Brendan Eich created JavaScript in 1995 at Netscape.

lessons.title: 1.2 Variables (var, let, const)
lessons.content:
# Variables in JavaScript

Variables are containers that store data values.

## Three Ways to Declare Variables

### ðŸ”¥ var (Old Way - Avoid)

```javascript
var name = 'John';
var age = 25;
name = 'Jane';  // Can reassign
var name = 'Bob';  // Can redeclare
```

### âš¡ let (Modern - Recommended)

```javascript
let score = 90;
score = 95;  // Can reassign
// let score = 85;  // Error - cannot redeclare
```

### ðŸ’  const (Modern - Best for Constants)

```javascript
const PI = 3.14159;
// PI = 3.14;  // Error - cannot reassign
const person = { name: 'John' };
person.age = 25;  // OK - modifying property
```

## Comparison Table

| Feature | var | let | const |
| **Scope** | Function | Block | Block |
| **Reassign** | Yes | Yes | No |
| **Redeclare** | Yes | No | No |
| **Use** | Avoid | Variables | Constants |
lessons.expectedOutput:
Radius: 5
Area: 78.53975
New Radius: 10
New Area: 314.159

quizQuestions.text: Which keyword is best for storing constants?
quizQuestions.explanation: const is used for constants that won't change.

lessons.title: 1.3 Data Types (Number, String, Boolean, Null, Undefined)
lessons.content:
# Data Types in JavaScript

JavaScript has dynamic typing - variables can hold any data type.

## Primitive Types

### ðŸ”¥ Number

```javascript
const age = 25;
const height = 5.9;
const result = 10 / 3;  // 3.333...
console.log(typeof age);  // "number"
```

### âš¡ String

```javascript
const name = 'John';        // Single quotes
const text = "Hello";       // Double quotes
const message = `Hi ${name}`; // Template literal
```

### ðŸ’  Boolean

```javascript
const isActive = true;
const isDeleted = false;
console.log(typeof isActive);  // "boolean"
```

### ðŸ“ Undefined

```javascript
let x;  // No value assigned
console.log(x);  // undefined
```

### ðŸ“¦ Null

```javascript
let user = null;  // Intentionally empty
console.log(user);  // null
```

### ðŸŽ¯ Object

```javascript
const person = {
    name: 'John',
    age: 30,
    city: 'New York'
};
console.log(person.name);  // John
```

### ðŸ”” Array

```javascript
const colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue'];
console.log(colors[0]);  // red
console.log(colors.length);  // 3
```
lessons.expectedOutput:
Age: 25 - Type: number
Name: Alice - Type: string
Is Student: true - Type: boolean
Person: { name: 'Alice', age: 25, gpa: 3.8 }
Scores: [ 90, 85, 95, 88 ]
First score: 90
Number of scores: 4

quizQuestions.text: What data type does the expression 'Hello' + 5 return?
quizQuestions.explanation: In JavaScript, string + number results in a string: 'Hello5'

lessons.title: 1.4 Operators (Arithmetic, Comparison, Logical)
lessons.content:
# Operators in JavaScript

## Arithmetic Operators

### ðŸ”¥ Basic Operations

```javascript
const a = 20, b = 8;
console.log(a + b);     // 28 (addition)
console.log(a - b);     // 12 (subtraction)
console.log(a * b);     // 160 (multiplication)
console.log(a / b);     // 2.5 (division)
console.log(a % b);     // 4 (modulus/remainder)
console.log(a ** 2);    // 400 (exponentiation)
```

### âš¡ Increment & Decrement

```javascript
let x = 5;
console.log(x++);       // 5 (use then increment)
console.log(x);         // 6
console.log(++x);       // 7 (increment then use)
```

## Comparison Operators

**Return true or false**

```javascript
console.log(10 > 5);      // true (greater than)
console.log(10 < 5);      // false (less than)
console.log(10 >= 10);    // true
console.log(10 <= 5);     // false
console.log(10 === 10);   // true (strict equal)
console.log(10 == '10');  // true (loose equal)
console.log(10 !== 5);    // true (not equal)
```

## Logical Operators

### ðŸ”¥ AND (&&)

```javascript
console.log(true && true);    // true
console.log(true && false);   // false
if (age >= 18 && hasLicense) {
    console.log('Can drive');
}
```

### âš¡ OR (||)

```javascript
console.log(false || true);   // true
console.log(false || false);  // false
if (hasLicense || hasParent) {
    console.log('Can go');
}
```

### ðŸ’  NOT (!)

```javascript
console.log(!true);           // false
if (!isRaining) {
    console.log('Go outside');
}
```
lessons.expectedOutput:
Arithmetic:
20 + 8 = 28
20 - 8 = 12
20 * 8 = 160
20 / 8 = 2.5
20 % 8 = 4

Comparison:
20 > 8 = true
20 < 8 = false
20 === 20 = true

Logical:
Can drive: true
Stable: true

quizQuestions.text: What is the difference between == and ===?
quizQuestions.explanation: === checks both type and value, == only checks value (type coercion).

quizQuestions.text: What happens if you forget 'break' in a switch case?
quizQuestions.explanation: Without break, execution continues to the next case (fall-through behavior).

quizQuestions.text: What is the difference between break and continue?
options: break exits loop, continue skips iteration
quizQuestions.explanation: break completely exits the loop, continue skips current iteration and moves to next.

lessons.title: 3.3 Arrays & Methods
lessons.content:
# Arrays & Methods

## Array Basics

```javascript
const colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue'];
console.log(colors[0]);       // red
console.log(colors.length);   // 3
```

## Common Array Methods

### ðŸ”¥ push() & pop()

```javascript
const fruits = ['apple', 'banana'];
fruits.push('orange');  // Add at end
console.log(fruits);    // ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']

fruits.pop();           // Remove last
console.log(fruits);    // ['apple', 'banana']
```

### âš¡ shift() & unshift()

```javascript
const arr = [1, 2, 3];
arr.unshift(0);         // Add at start
console.log(arr);       // [0, 1, 2, 3]

arr.shift();            // Remove first
console.log(arr);       // [1, 2, 3]
```

### ðŸ’  map() - Transform

```javascript
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4];
const doubled = numbers.map(n => n * 2);
console.log(doubled);   // [2, 4, 6, 8]
```

### ðŸ“ filter() - Select

```javascript
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6];
const even = numbers.filter(n => n % 2 === 0);
console.log(even);      // [2, 4, 6]
```

### ðŸ“¦ reduce() - Combine

```javascript
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4];
const sum = numbers.reduce((acc, n) => acc + n, 0);
console.log(sum);       // 10
```

### âœ… forEach() - Loop

```javascript
const colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue'];
colors.forEach(color => console.log(color));
```
lessons.expectedOutput:
Doubled: [ 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 ]
Even: [ 2, 4 ]
Sum: 15
Names: [ 'Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie' ]
High scorers: [ { name: 'Alice', score: 90 }, { name: 'Charlie', score: 88 } ]
Average score: 84.33333333333333

quizQuestions.text: What does the map() method do?
quizQuestions.explanation: map() transforms each element using a function and returns new array.

quizQuestions.text: What is hoisting?
quizQuestions.explanation: Hoisting moves variable and function declarations to the top of their scope.

quizQuestions.text: What method selects multiple elements by class?
quizQuestions.explanation: querySelectorAll selects all matching elements; getElementsByClassName also works but querySelector* is preferred.

quizQuestions.text: What are the three states of a Promise?
quizQuestions.explanation: Promises have three states: pending (initial), fulfilled (success), and rejected (error).

quizQuestions.text: How do you save an object in localStorage?
quizQuestions.explanation: Objects must be converted to JSON string using JSON.stringify() before saving to localStorage.

title: LEVEL 6: Classes & Object-Oriented JS
description: Master blueprint-based programming and OOP design

Alice Average: 90.00
Bob Average: 75.00
New Average for Alice: 92.50

quizQuestions.text: Which method is called automatically when 'new Class()' is used?
quizQuestions.explanation: The constructor method is a special method for creating and initializing an object created with a class.

lessons.title: 6.2 Class Inheritance & super()
lessons.expectedOutput:
Tesla is starting... (Silently)
Charging with 500km range capacity.

quizQuestions.text: What does super() do in a constructor?
quizQuestions.explanation: In a child class constructor, super() must be called to initialize the parent class.

title: LEVEL 7: Functional Programming & Advanced Patterns
description: Write cleaner, more predictable code with FP

lessons.title: 7.1 Pure Functions & Side Effects
lessons.expectedOutput:
Original: 50000
Updated: 55000

quizQuestions.text: What is a side effect in JS?
quizQuestions.explanation: Any modification of state or interaction with the outside world (like console.log or changing a variable outside the function) is a side effect.

lessons.title: 7.2 Closures Deep Dive & Currying
lessons.expectedOutput:
Double 5: 10
Triple 5: 15
Admins: [ 'John', 'Bob' ]

quizQuestions.text: What is Currying?
options: A way to speed up JS
quizQuestions.explanation: Currying breaks down a multi-argument function into a series of single-argument functions.

title: LEVEL 8: Modules & Modern Tooling
description: Structure large projects with ES Modules

lessons.title: 8.1 ES Modules (Import/Export)
lessons.expectedOutput:
Format: (Current Date)
Public ID: PUB_SEC

quizQuestions.text: How many default exports can a file have?
quizQuestions.explanation: A module can have many named exports but only one default export.

lessons.title: 9.1 JavaScript Power User Exam
lessons.content:
# JavaScript Final Exam

**Congratulations!** You've reached the final stage. This exam covers everything from Level 1 to Level 8.

## Topics covered:
- **Fundamentals**: Variables, types, scope.
- **Logic**: Iteration, conditionals, async flow.
- **Architecture**: Objects, Prototype chain, ES6 Classes.
- **Modern JS**: Destructuring, Modules, HOFs.

## Passing Criteria:
- 15/20 correct answers required for the 'Zero to Hero' Certificate.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Status: Graduating...
(After 1s)
You hired as Hero Developer!

quizQuestions.text: Which of these is NOT a Primitive in JS?
quizQuestions.explanation: Arrays are Objects in JavaScript, not primitives.

quizQuestions.text: What is the result of typeof null?
quizQuestions.explanation: This is a famous bug in JS that will never be fixed for backward compatibility: typeof null is 'object'.

quizQuestions.text: Which method returns a new array with elements that pass a test?
quizQuestions.explanation: filter() creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.

quizQuestions.text: What is a Closure?
quizQuestions.explanation: A closure is the combination of a function bundled together with references to its surrounding state (the lexical environment).

quizQuestions.text: What does async/await do?
options: Handles promises with synchronous style syntax
quizQuestions.explanation: Async/await is syntactic sugar built on top of Promises, making asynchronous code more readable.
